context: In particular, total carbonyl compounds ranged from 0.1% to 1.3% and from 0.1% to 0.4% in wine samples produced by S. cerevisiae “Southern” and “Northern” strains, respectively (Table 1). Acetaldehyde was produced by 35% of “Southern” and 25% of “Northern” yeasts (Fig. 1). Decanal was formed by 45% of “Southern” yeasts, while “Northern” yeasts didn't form this compound. As regards ketones, 2-heptanone and 2-nonanone were recovered in 45% and in 35% of wine samples produced by “Southern” Italy strains, respectively, and in 37.5% and in 25% of wine samples obtained with “Northern” yeasts, respectively (Fig. 1). Other aromatic compounds were determined in low amounts both in wines produced by S. cerevisiae “Southern” and “Northern” yeasts (Table 1). In summary, S. cerevisiae isolated from Southern Italy grapes were able to produce more volatile compounds than those from Northern Italy. Consequently, yeasts from South Italy can produce potentially more complex wines from a specific must.

The focus is on the production of various carbonyl compounds, including 2-heptanone, by different strains of S. cerevisiae in wine fermentation. While sulfur dioxide is commonly used as a preservative in winemaking, its specific interaction with 2-heptanone or its role in the fermentation process is not discussed, indicating a lack of direct relevance between the two terms.
